Patients

What to Expect at Your Eye Exam

Wait times

  • While we respect your time and strive to be on time with our appointments, we do provide emergency on call services for the Halton region, and wait times may vary.
  • Plan for 1-2 hrs total for your visit.

Pre-testing visit

  • Your appointment will usually be divided into two visits: a pre-testing visit with the ophthalmic technician, and a consultation with a doctor.
  • At the pre-testing visit, a highly skilled ophthalmic technician will see you and take a complete medical and ophthalmological history. The ophthalmic technician will measure your vision, eye pressure, corneal thickness, and take photographs of your eye. The ophthalmic technician may also perform additional diagnostic tests if requested by the doctor.
  • At the end of the pre-testing visit, you may be given a mini set of dilating drops to use at home prior to upcoming visit with the doctor for consultation; this allows you to save time and wait less at the office.
  • At the end of the pre-testing visit, if you are returning for a cataract consultation, you may also be given artificial tears to use for one week prior to your surgery consultation; this allows us to ensure we obtain the most accurate results when we take your measurements for surgery.

Same Day Testing

  • If you travel from a distance to see us, or simply have difficulty coming to two separate appointments, please let us know, and we will do our best to accommodate you so that pre-testing with the technician and consultation with the doctor are scheduled on the same day.

Consultation

  • Your doctor will review your images, testing, and reports with you to formulate a diagnosis and create a mutually agreed upon management plan.
  • While we try to limit the number of people in the office at one time due to Covid-19, and generally ask that your family member/support person wait outside the office, if you feel it would be helpful for you, you can ask to have a family member/support person accompany you at the consultation. Please advise us of this beforehand so we can schedule appointments accordingly.

Surgery Counselling

  • If you require cataract surgery, after seeing the doctor, the next step will be to meet with the surgery coordinator.
  • Our surgery coordinator is a registered nurse and operating room nurse who will help to prepare you for surgery.
  • She will take measurements for surgery, schedule your surgery, and advise you as to how to prepare pre-operatively, as well as what to expect post-operatively.
  • She will provide you with a prescription for eye drops to use pre- and post-operatively as well as instructions.
  • Where possible, we will try to schedule your appointment in such a way that you can see the surgery counsellor on the same day as your consultation with the doctor, to save you a visit. In some cases, where we cannot accommodate this, or if your eye is too dry to do the testing required for surgery, we may ask you to return on another day after using artificial tears for one week.
  • She has had many years of experience both working in the operating room, and as a surgical coordinator, and is a great resource who can help to address any questions or concerns you may have.
